Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be a private person with a unique personality, always carrying a camera. She wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, she would have her camera around her neck and wouldn’t be seen again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.”

Maier was knowledgeable about theater and film. Although she was not very social, she often walked the streets with her camera and engaged with people, some of whom she interviewed on tape. She seemed to be dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “Nothing stopped her.”

Maier’s work is pure art; she did not create it for commercial purposes. Her photographs often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. “What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style independently. “Was Vivian sophisticated enough to do this, or did she borrow ideas from others?”

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began taking his own pictures. “As I grew as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It was the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I was holding something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known and ensure Vivian Maier is remembered in history.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she remained calm, especially for someone in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels part of the success. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmothers.” She also mentioned that it bothers her when people assume her book is not a philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part being half the length of the previous one. This structure makes the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she aimed to create a book with structural patterns that readers could explore if they wanted to, but that they were not essential to enjoy the story.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Surprisingly, Catton did not plan the story in advance. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creatively I could get out of the situation I had created.” One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in screenwriting. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied, her enthusiasm evident.

She becomes animated when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice how much my imagination changes when I’m in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas to be surrounded by more people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a child, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his father's garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has made a living by handcrafting steel-string acoustic guitars. He expresses his fascination with the guitar, wondering how two pieces of wood can create such beautiful sounds and how different types of wood can produce different tones.

Jonny learned to play his brother's guitar at the age of eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he turned sixteen. Instead of getting a job to save money for one, he decided to build it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and learned how to assemble them. Although the bass was his first complete instrument, he had been building model boats and airplanes with his brothers, so he was familiar with the process. His father taught them how to use tools, and he had also repaired instruments for friends.

Jonny's bass guitar turned out well, but he had not yet considered a career in guitar-making. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university because it involved design, which he liked. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out, feeling that he was too independent for it. He realized that guitar-making was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound, and he thought it might be a more practical career than pure art since it produced items people could use.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to support himself. His early guitars were sold at the cost of materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he was able to charge more. Even now, nearly forty years later, he describes his work as "still scratching a living," as he can only make about ten guitars a year, limiting his income.

In the beginning, Jonny focused on getting his name out there. He attended music festivals on weekends, encouraging musicians to try his guitars and spread the word. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he initially struggled with this aspect of the business.

Jonny believes that it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were valuable, even though the UK has always had excellent instrument-making courses. Now, British-made guitars have gained the recognition they deserve.

He thinks that valuable skills can be learned in classrooms, and he encourages new makers to take available courses. However, he also believes that there is no substitute for learning through experience. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. He explains that if the back of a guitar is too thin or too thick, it won't sound good. He feels that being self-taught allows for a broader understanding, while learning from someone else may limit you to just one method.

Any discussion about English conversation, like any English conversation, usually starts with the weather. In this traditional way, I will quote the well-known comment from the eighteenth-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many commentators either stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that when we talk about the weather, we are genuinely interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly interesting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. Therefore, he finds it hard to understand why the English are so preoccupied with it. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. He argues that while we may not have dramatic weather, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be completely sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather serves as a way for English people to connect with each other. For instance, phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not genuine questions about the weather; they are common greetings or ways to start a conversation. In this sense, English weather talk is similar to "social grooming" among monkeys, who spend time grooming each other to bond socially.

There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some writers claim that the English talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to break the ice before discussing other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. This frequent use of weather talk can give outsiders the impression that English people talk about little else. An English conversation might start with a weather-related greeting, move to some light weather discussion, and then return to weather talk during pauses. This is why many people, including some English commentators, think that the English are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build a structure that is 120 km long and 5 meters high nearly 1900 years ago. The students were excited about this trip, choosing it over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to provide context about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. 

Having had a successful teaching career, Alice felt she was stepping into the unknown. She compared teaching to acting, saying it was physically demanding, while writing was exciting but less exhausting. Her former colleagues envied her because she still connected with children through her stories. Alice aims to fill a gap in children's fiction. She noted that much of today’s adolescent fiction focuses on negative experiences, which, while well-written, often presents dark realities or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books are different.

Alice always taught English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She is motivated by her love for children and is fascinated by the moment when a child goes from boredom to interest and from confusion to understanding. She enjoys the challenge of engaging bored children. 

Her decision to write her first novel was inspired by the realization that her two sons were leaving home, creating an "empty nest," and a suggestion from her head teacher to take a creative writing course. Initially, Alice was hesitant to spend her summer on a course she thought unnecessary. However, she had to submit her best piece of fiction to be accepted, which she only learned a few days before the course started. She quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their unborn child. After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work positively and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she requested a year off from her school to write her first novel. Alice's husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was crucial in editing her novel. Alice believes they complement each other; he improves her writing by changing sentence structures and suggesting word changes, while her instinct is to add more scenes. This difference highlights the roles of a fiction writer and an editor.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny in a car on the roads and Alistair riding a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England, with both brothers racing to the same finish point. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! The views here are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in full winter cycling gear, was also eager. “Honestly,” he said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. While the car could handle the climb, Alistair faced a steep 25 percent incline right from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sped away on his bike, taking a path straight up the hill, while Jonny got into his car and hit the road. The big question was: who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faced a challenge. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he joked to the cameraman in his car. After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the slope, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion made his way up the hill with his bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top, where he could see the open ground ahead. With the sun shining, he pushed himself to go faster.

Meanwhile, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in the villages of Yorkshire were not built for speed. He had to carefully navigate a tight corner and drive through a stream that had formed on the road. Once past the last village, he was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny accelerated down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the opposite side. 

With determination, Alistair pushed hard and then suddenly hit the brakes as he reached the finish line. He looked up and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they replied no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!” Moments later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a peaceful atmosphere that separates you from the outside world. This quiet is good for my game. The biggest challenge in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence is broken by applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize there are fifteen thousand people watching every move I make, nor that millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the most important match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I shared with my friends my dream of playing there and winning. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice in the finals. The loss in 2006 was not too hard; I was just happy to have made it that far. Federer won easily, but my defeat in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it hurts more when you have a chance and let it slip away.

Toni, who is usually tough on me, surprisingly told me not to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I felt he didn’t understand; I thought that might have been my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments are more important than others, and I had missed a big one in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to comfort me, but he turned out to be right. Another chance came in 2008, just a year later. I was confident I had learned from my previous defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. 

The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we avoided talking about the match. I didn’t have to tell them not to mention it; they understood that I was already mentally preparing for the game. From that moment until the match started, that mental space was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” This woman was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Jane Goodall became famous when Britain’s National Geographical Society published articles and made documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writings, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real accomplishments. Many articles and interviews tell her story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects rather than her scientific work. 

People have portrayed her in various ways: as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading zoologist and a pioneer in her field. 

Her main achievement is that she greatly improved our understanding of the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans. We also did not realize that chimpanzees share similar emotions with us or that their social structures are surprisingly similar to ours. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Her book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is the most important work in chimpanzee research and serves as an encyclopedia on the subject. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and since chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we view ourselves. Even as a child, there were signs of the biologist she would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, she disappeared, prompting a search by the police, neighbors, and family. After a frantic search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had crawled into a henhouse, hidden in the straw, and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to fans of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she explains, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” 

Shirley discusses what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even very famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known names want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she recalls, “the studio manager suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors are often asked to voice small boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and lots of paperwork, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from her throat and to avoid always sounding like the same child. She collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this field help,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for work is intense, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley advises. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached her current success – near the top of her field – through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also believes a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, such as tax lawyer or auto parts manufacturer. The idea of making a living by drawing simple doodles, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. Yet, some people do just that. 

Becoming a cartoonist is not the same for everyone, but most who succeed have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, loving comic strips, contributing to school publications, and being known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to various companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper looking for political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. Within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical requirements are low, it is still a challenging job. You should only pursue this career if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to find a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t enjoy. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? In the past, many cartoonists could find steady jobs with different newspapers and magazines. However, those days are fading. Today, cartooning is often an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you must not only create your work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are artistic geniuses but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. However, the truth is that it is more likely no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster; it could actually be a lucky opportunity!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of even useless items, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We parted ways, but in the following days and years, I felt deep sadness for what I had done.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He wrote, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold several times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it might be outdated but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I would have given him anything, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my belongings, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange situation!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the calming sound of the instrument, which was gentle and flattering for beginners. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound terrible when played by someone just starting out. However, I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played simpler music. This was also the time of punk music, where people who couldn’t play well could still become rock stars.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my smiling parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play but quickly stood up, putting a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are meant to be played standing. My fingers instinctively knew where to go. I couldn’t have drawn a diagram for the chords I wanted to play, but my hands just moved into position. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to form a chord. The electric guitar is not really meant for solo playing. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

There has been much discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Many insomniacs I interviewed emphasized that sleep is essential for our overall well-being. Interestingly, those who have the most trouble sleeping often understand its importance the best. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There has not been much conversation about them. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early due to an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the stage where we have the most vivid dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning that someone who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years dreaming. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose.

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of art. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively?

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and often surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may allow us to discover new patterns and combinations that challenge our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are awakened from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to think outside the box and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a form of creativity. Personally, I find that I write better after experiencing intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely recall, seems to inspire my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I am not sure how it works, but it does seem effective.

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function well. We must think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with cheerful photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, Susie can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits with ease. It seems unusual that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any around,” Susie says casually. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

The reason is that Susie is very popular. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted many famous artists' works, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors genuinely love art, some are more interested in status. One celebrity likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie’s copy instead.

Susie is transparent about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she aims to make it look as authentic as possible because she believes that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she always signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and although she knows people who have profited from that, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. Susie admits she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists.

Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little money. Looking back, she sees that this experience helped her develop her skills and fostered her love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time but is glad to have found a more financially rewarding career.

When younger artists seek her advice, Susie emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that while impressionists painted quickly and freely, they were also very careful, and achieving that balance is quite challenging.

Given her talent, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own original works. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than her copies? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, such as oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not exceptional. It’s like living on plain food after enjoying meals prepared by a top chef. Ultimately, Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest sailor. This obsession began in her childhood. She felt a unique connection with her boats, as if they were one entity. When she returned to land, daily life seemed unimportant, and she often longed to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in dangerous situations. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she invited me to see the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher, where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how meticulously she planned her supplies, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in maintaining the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. To her, the boat was her entire world, and she cared for it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen views the world as a fragile boat with limited resources. A significant moment for her occurred during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she participated in a bird survey for albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things in a new light. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her: it felt like humanity had taken what it wanted and moved on without care.

When I visited Ellen's office, she was finishing a passionate conference call about the urgent need to protect the planet. She explained that resources like coal, oil, and gas are finite and must be used wisely. Initially, her message was about reducing consumption, but she later realized there was a more positive approach. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, such as industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, discussing our dependence on non-renewable resources with government and business leaders. She admits she is not an expert but describes herself as a sponge, eager to learn. The current environmental crisis is something she cannot ignore. Compared to sailing, which felt selfish, her new mission is about finding ways to make her voice impactful.

Ellen also founded the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that aims to inspire young people to create a sustainable future through business and education. She misses the adventure of being at sea, as it is a part of her identity. At sea, she felt connected to everything around her, focused on survival and her goals. She acknowledges that her new message is more complex than simply saying, "I want to be the fastest around the world." While she once achieved that, her current work is even more meaningful to her.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. He hopes to encourage other kids to explore the outdoors instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to complete the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 14.

I spoke with several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They believed that while Jordan might be physically strong, they were unsure if he had the emotional strength needed. They also questioned whether a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing.

The Romero family has heard these concerns before. Paul said, "I know there is criticism, but I can't focus on it – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help us. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature." 

I also wonder about Jordan's reasons for wanting to climb. Is it just his father's ambition pushing him? Paul insists, "This project is not about me becoming famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought it was something to do later in life, but we decided, 'Why not do it now?' We talk to him often to ensure he still wants to do it."

When I asked Jordan what he enjoys about this challenge, he said, "I just focus on reaching my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to set a record. The more exciting the record, the more attention it gets. This creates a challenge for Jordan. While some may say that focusing on achievements takes away from enjoyment, if he wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you don’t know who composed the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This situation is concerning for classical music lovers. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. This is hard to believe. 

So, why is interest in classical music declining? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast conversations, quick games, and rapid thoughts. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to enjoy, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Additionally, pop music often deals with topics that interest teenagers, while classical music usually does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would gather to play music together, and playing an instrument was important. Now, we can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people enjoy classical concerts, but I do know that if teenagers’ parents love something, they often try to avoid it.

Some people blame schools for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many students are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their preferred music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother understood how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she noticed signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of trailing behind like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll probably be kicked out soon anyway, so I might as well get it over with.” She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. The horses were well cared for, and she noticed that immediately. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best one!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. They can’t be far.” She was thrilled to find that the room with the riding gear was unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything around her. Her old school nickname had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I really mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think we could become great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling exhilarated as a gentle breeze brushed against her cheek. She sensed that Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his calm confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven.” He remembers that swimming and surfing were his main interests back then. At 13, while in high school, he posted a few videos online.

These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans began to comment online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was incredible. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer, training hard with top coaches. However, record labels showed interest in him, and he faced a difficult decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving to the US with his family. Cody decided to take the leap. “It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends about his move to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m the quiet kid,” he recalls, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.”

So, Cody packed his bags and traveled halfway around the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to stay grounded. 

Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.”

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to opportunities, even when it’s scary. “Everything happened so quickly and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans. It’s something many people dream of achieving, but I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags into place. Last week, I had worked long hours with most of the adults in town, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather, however, didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand still on the curtain, I scanned the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. On either side were fragile ice shelves, and downstream was solid ice. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I noticed a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket, checking the pocket for my lucky chain—a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, as only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. 

I patted the chain and went to the kitchen. “Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” “Thanks, Mom,” I replied, heading down the hallway. I almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he stepped out of his room. “Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking,” I said, even though my wetsuit made it clear. He often gets angry, and lately, it has been harder for me to ignore it. “What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His harsh words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a sympathetic smile. “Don’t mind him. He’s…” “...not himself at the moment,” I finished for her. I held back from saying he has always been like this. Like my mom, I try to be understanding. 

When I was younger, he was my hero, especially when he showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold!” I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said, “if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study, where she saw an unframed painting on the table, leaning against the wall. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." 

Jess looked closely at the painting. A river took up most of the scene; it was not a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a fantasy. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, with just a hint of green that the eye almost missed, drawing attention to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she found it captivating, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, even though she tried to sound casual. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings; he just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt strangely significant to her, but she couldn't explain why. 

Then she noticed something else. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." 

"Exactly. It's strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. But since he hasn't finished it yet, maybe he plans to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." 

"Mum! You should have known better." 

"I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess his response." 

Jess didn't need to guess. She knew Grandpa would have said, "It's not the artist's job to explain a painting. Each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. Painting is hard work without having to explain it to everyone." 

Mum laughed and added, "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." 

"Inspire?" 

"Yes, someone who motivates an artist." Jess understood the term. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse was not helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. 

"He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big hole. That’s something that could have happened. I’m not claiming it did, just that it was a possibility. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as often happens. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This kind of thing happens to me quite often. I’m a bit unlucky in that way.

What I was really doing was trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. Now, I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, so I was thrilled when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it’s a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom belongs to Mum and Dad; the back one is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. Then, when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only issue is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimeters off the bottom of it... That’s when I had an idea. If I couldn’t cut the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" items from the regular-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the book, I knew it would be challenging to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how it should be portrayed. I used the original illustrations from the book as a guide because I wanted to avoid criticism for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, which made filming more complicated.

A key aspect was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on their borrowing adventures, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really embraced the idea. The coins we used were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which often made the crew laugh. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. A crucial part of the production was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they would look like doll clothes. This made it very difficult for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug to avoid a smooth look. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the scenes away from the Borrowers' home were filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had created 2,000 sketches. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for daytime special effects work, so I spent three months working nights. We had to work quickly; I once filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. In the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take for the chaos to start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of touring and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet regular kids. How about a kid whose mom works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says, typing my last name. That’s one good thing; few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One moment, it’s printing,” she says. Then she tears the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature is my first class. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes. 

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my normal but clever outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. No one will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we need to read this year, she actually lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have many options. Should I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a studio right by the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, fiddling with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Great.

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Both boys and girls cannot just go to school and blend in; being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and lacking ambition is seen as laziness. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, explains, “People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers face today. We have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life.” Despite these pressures being common in teenage life today, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label the entire generation this way. 

Kristen Loose argues that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She acknowledges that she often has her phone nearby, but not for trivial reasons. It is not just for texting friends; it is a tool that helps teenagers manage their lives. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might be listening to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities now require constant attention from already busy teens.

Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight. Their schedules are filled with school, after-school activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They then have to wake up and do it all over again the next day, often getting less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens admitted to falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or watching TV; instead, she dedicates it to volunteer work. She says, “People often think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests.” However, Olsen finds that her favorite part of the week is volunteering. “I love helping others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community.”

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and push the world forward. There will always be a new generation of students making a difference before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this small group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project combines astronomy and adventure, which is likely why teenagers participate. I joined them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to capture images of shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail.

As night falls, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside, there is a camera, an altitude measuring device, and a thermometer to track temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers are placed on the outside of the lunch box to help them find it later. They use a gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, to inflate the balloon, which gradually expands to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get the tank, but he didn’t mind. For these kids, such efforts are normal.

Finally, it’s time for lift-off. They count down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon starts to rise. Some of the teenagers run after it, shining powerful flashlights to track its path in the dark sky. There is a moment of silence and a shared sense of wonder as the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside, gazing at a sky so clear it’s hard to believe they are only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I see a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” one girl whispers. “I know,” replies another. Suddenly, a meteor streaks across the sky.

As the balloon rises, the air pressure decreases, causing it to expand until it is nearly the size of a house. Then it pops with a loud bang. A parachute ensures the equipment inside the lunch box lands safely back on Earth. The students will retrieve it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” says the group’s leader, noting they have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us become more familiar with the landscape in a way we normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box landed on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader explains. “What seems wild to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box, which was in a canyon on a flat rock near a waterfall. Unfortunately, the camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was disappointing, it provided a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and their effects above mountains. It also became another exciting story to share with anyone who asks.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she turned fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she had dismissed this interest before, she helped him with a science project and came across an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized she wanted to pursue this field.

I asked Chloe what support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time. She recalled meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite his youth. Although she was nervous, he was friendly and patient, which made her feel more comfortable.

I brought up how palaeontologists are often portrayed in movies and TV shows. Chloe expressed her frustration, noting that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs but often misrepresent palaeontologists. She feels they are usually shown as either quirky geniuses or socially awkward individuals, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explained that her job is very diverse. She spends time digging for dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific papers. Although not always required, she also believes in the importance of communicating scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. She wants to inspire them to learn about science, using dinosaurs as a way to spark their interest in the natural world.

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She noted that the producers were knowledgeable, and her role was mainly to ensure accuracy, such as confirming that the dinosaurs depicted lived during the same time period. The program attracted viewers of all ages because it presented dinosaurs in a way that was much more realistic than in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes that dinosaurs continue to captivate us and remain a focus of research because they appeal to our natural curiosity and desire for discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to explore, and Palaeontology offers a unique way to travel back in time.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are just six years old, you probably know that you are not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not "there" anymore; it’s "here." So if you think you might be "there," you should really be asking, "Are we here yet?" 

Parents often wish they were "there" more than anyone else, especially when they hear that question repeatedly during long car trips. Think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside. Meanwhile, one of your parents is in the front seat, managing snacks and the radio, making sure everything goes smoothly.

But then, something unexpected happens—usually caused by my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat, which is not okay! I respond by putting my foot on his side, and soon we are both fighting for space. Our parents have to reach back to separate us while driving, telling Tim to stay in his own seat. This calms things down for a bit, and we can enjoy the scenery again.

Later, while I’m trying to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing air in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry, and soon there’s more yelling and swerving as our parents try to keep control of the car.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle our questions. When we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often replies, "Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car." When we point out that we are still on the highway, he says, "Oh, then maybe we’re not there yet." This usually keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults quickly get out of the car and move away from us kids. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is no, you are not "there" yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve staring at screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate with each other.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was further developed in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players either win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the book. He recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something like that.”

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as gifts but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he began redesigning games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up introduced even more storytelling elements. Leacock explains, “It’s like an electronic game where you develop characters, learn new rules, and the story changes as you play.”

Interestingly, the rise of video games has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a major games company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.” 

For a while, video games allowed for social interaction in arcades or through multiplayer games played in the same room. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This led some people to seek out ways to play games with others in person again. 

As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with many setbacks. He mentions that his mother was an incredible singer who introduced him to the guitar.
