According to the Pew Research Centre in the USA, only 26% of Americans now rely on newspapers for news, down from 45% in 2001. Many people confidently predict that printed newspapers will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that traditional media often survive longer than expected. 

For example, in 1835, a journalist in New York claimed that books and theatre were finished, and that newspapers would become the main source of social life. Yet, theatre has survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even in the age of TV, and cinema has continued to do well despite the rise of videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008.

Interestingly, newspapers were once considered a new form of media. It took centuries for them to become the primary source of news, which was made possible by advancements like the steam press, railways, and the telegraph in the mid-19th century. This shift also involved a new understanding that the world is always changing, and we need regular updates—an idea that was foreign to people in medieval times. Back then, life was seen as cyclical, with only seasonal changes and unpredictable disasters like famine or disease.

Before the 19th century, journalism was not a full-time profession that could support a living. Even then, there was little reason for most people to seek news regularly. The fixed schedule and format of newspapers can be limiting. In contrast, online news allows readers to access information based on their own interests and the urgency of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms help personalize news, and updates can be provided almost instantly when significant stories break. There are no space limitations, allowing for more detailed narratives and analyses.

However, many news providers seem focused on being the first to report rather than on promoting understanding. This creates confusion, similar to the medieval marketplace where news was mixed with rumors and misunderstandings. Newspapers have often struggled to explain how the world works. They may be facing extinction, or perhaps, as the internet adds to our sense of living in a chaotic universe, newspapers might find a way to guide us toward greater wisdom and understanding.

If humans truly belonged under the moon and stars, we would walk happily in the dark, just like many night creatures that thrive in it. However, we are daytime beings, with eyes designed for sunlight. This fact is deeply rooted in our genetics, even if we don’t often think of ourselves as daytime creatures, just as we don’t think of ourselves as primates or mammals. This understanding helps explain our impact on the night. We have changed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control is similar to building a dam on a river. While it has benefits, it also leads to problems known as light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study. 

Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design that allows artificial light to shine into the sky instead of focusing it down where it is needed. Bad lighting brightens the night, changing the light levels and patterns that many living beings, including us, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light spreads into nature, it affects important life activities like migration, reproduction, and feeding. 

For most of human history, the term ‘light pollution’ would have been meaningless. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the most populated city on Earth. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and there were no public gaslights in the streets for another seven years. From a distance, you would likely smell London before seeing its faint glow. We have illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that is far from the truth. There are many nocturnal species among mammals. Light is a strong biological force that attracts many creatures. Scientists have noted that songbirds and seabirds can be ‘captured’ by bright lights, circling endlessly until they fall. Birds that migrate at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, and young birds on their first journeys are especially affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours because of artificial light.

Initially, it was believed that light pollution only impacted astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. While most of us may not require a perfect view of the stars for our work, we, like many other creatures, need darkness. Rejecting darkness is pointless. It is as vital for our health as light is; disrupting our natural rhythms can lead to various health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping reflects the natural light changes on Earth. These rhythms are so essential to our existence that disturbing them is like changing our center of gravity. 

Ultimately, humans are just as affected by light pollution as frogs living near a bright highway. By living in our own artificial light, we have disconnected ourselves from our evolutionary and cultural roots—the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. In a significant way, light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe and the vastness of our existence, which is best understood against the backdrop of a dark night filled with the Milky Way overhead.

The founder of a large international company recently said that his business will stop tracking how much paid holiday time employees take. This decision seems to be inspired by a similar policy from an internet company. The founder mentioned that he got the idea from a cheerful email from his daughter, which many newspapers have shared. However, this way of announcing the change feels like a superficial attempt to make a potentially unkind policy seem friendlier. 

Is this idea practical? The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational corporation has 50,000 employees and many different services, including finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want, as long as it doesn’t hurt the business" seems more suitable for a smaller company where employees know each other’s workloads better. The founder stated that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel completely sure that their absence won’t harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? No matter how much work you finish before a holiday, there will always be more waiting when you return. 

Following these guidelines might make employees hesitant to take time off or feel guilty about doing so. This guilt can lead to stress, and if workers don’t take enough leave, it could reduce productivity over time. There may also be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. In many corporate environments, there is a culture of working late, which could lead to a "no holiday" mindset in a company with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. 

If the security and rights that come with statutory leave are removed, employees might feel they cannot take the time off they need for fear of being seen as lazy. They would lose the legal protection that guarantees their leave. This policy could create a situation where workers feel unable to take their entitled leave, or they might continue to rely on their statutory rights, making the new policy ineffective. 

Modern technology allows us to receive work messages anytime and anywhere, blurring the lines between work and personal time. The internet company started its unlimited leave policy after employees questioned how this new work style fit with the old time-off rules. If the company can’t track how much time employees spend working, why should it apply a different standard for time off? However, a problem with having no set working hours is that it can feel like every hour is a working hour. Employees may never know if their hours are being monitored, leading them to self-discipline in potentially harmful ways. 

Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have the right to a minimum amount of paid annual leave because rest and leisure are essential for their mental and physical health. The benefits of increased morale, creativity, and productivity that are expected from unlimited leave can exist without ensuring worker well-being. Therefore, I am skeptical that allowing employees to take as much holiday as they want is either the true goal or likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in a field evaluate a scientific research paper before it is published. This process is often seen as a way to ensure the quality of research, as it aims to prevent flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. However, the review process can delay publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to maintain trust in published research? The answer is both yes and no. 

While I still believe in the importance of some form of review before publication, I see changes happening in scientific publishing. The rise of preprints—drafts of papers shared online without peer review—plays a significant role in this change. Preprints allow researchers to quickly share new findings so that others can read, critique, and build upon them. Unfortunately, publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which can distort the motivations of authors and reviewers. 

The competition for publication in prestigious journals encourages scientists to produce high-quality work, but it can also lead to shortcuts, where important data is omitted to make a paper more appealing. Reviewers often focus on whether a paper is good enough for a specific journal rather than its overall quality. For top journals, the decision can depend more on how timely or newsworthy a paper is rather than its scientific merit. 

These issues are well-known, yet many are reluctant to change the current system. However, as biologist Ron Vale recently suggested, preprints could offer a solution without drastically changing the norm. Although preprints have been around for twenty years, they have not been widely accepted. This slow adoption is partly due to scientists' conservative nature and the misconception that journals will not accept papers that have been posted as preprints. There is also concern that publishing unreviewed papers could lead to poor-quality research, but this has not happened so far.

Preprints may lack formal peer review, but authors understand that their work is open to critique from a global community of reviewers. For example, psychology professor Tanya Elks shared her experience of critiquing a published paper. In the traditional peer review system, the original authors might block critical feedback, but by posting a preprint, both sides could engage in open discussion. This transparency allows readers to assess the quality of the arguments presented. 

Preprint archives facilitate informal scientific discussions that were once limited to private correspondence. They also provide a platform for sharing negative results, which are often overlooked by journals focused on new discoveries. Additionally, papers on preprint archives tend to be read and cited more frequently, demonstrating the effectiveness of this method of sharing research. By embracing the internet's culture of openness and collaboration, preprints can help shift the focus back to the quality of the research itself, rather than the prestige of the publication.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it is "a painting in words." However, these answers usually do not satisfy either me or them. One day, I asked a group of students to choose an object and write two paragraphs about it: one as a scientist would, describing it objectively, and another from the object's perspective, titled "Poem." One student chose an oxygen mask and wrote: 

"Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I help people breathe. I am used only in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me."

This unusual choice helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to laughter and meaningful discussions. When I was in school, I found poetry confusing. To me, every poem felt like a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand and feel deeply. After school, most people pay less attention to poetry. Occasionally, a poem stands out because it is not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or because you don’t understand it right away. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we hope to find in poems? We might expect them to express deep emotions, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp humor. The answer seems to be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information or sharp analysis, we read articles. Novels let us escape, paintings please our eyes, and music combines lyrics, instruments, and melody in a way that is hard to match. However, one thing that poems can offer is ambiguity, which is common in everyday life.

Searching online for "poem" leads to "poetry," defined as "a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language." This sounds impressive, but it overlooks the word's origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek word poí?ma, meaning "a thing made," and a poet is "a maker of things." So, if a poem is a created thing, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals—uncontrollable and unpredictable—or to machines—carefully designed and precise—depending on their perspective. However, these comparisons often break down upon closer examination.

The most valuable part of trying to define a poem through comparison is the discussion it generates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about both. It encourages us to rethink our usual ways of thinking and see ordinary things in a new way. Poems can be mental objects, especially since song lyrics often stick in our minds. The combination of words and melody has a strong impact, as shown in schoolyard rhymes like "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But can words sometimes hurt, like sticks and stones? 

Think about a poem in a newspaper or magazine, staring at you: a poem can resonate deeply like nothing else, even though it is just ink on paper, like the prose around it. What about the empty space around the poem—space that could have been used for a longer article or an ad? A poem is written and rewritten like any article, story, or novel, but it is not usually created to be sold. Publishers send out press releases and review copies of poetry collections, but few expect them to make back their printing costs. A poem exists not as a product for sale, but for its own sake. Because of its unique position in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector shortly after getting married. At that time, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been wiser to spend it on something practical for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy. I have always enjoyed feeling connected to the past. After the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had a few hours to spare and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a nearby spot known for old farming equipment. When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down about half a meter and lay in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. Having previously dug up brass curtain rails, I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, beautifully designed loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before—the Great Torc, displayed in the British Museum. It is the most famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I was holding.

I took it to my car, and at every stoplight on the way home, I looked at the torc on the passenger seat. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first proper cleaning it had in centuries. “Marion!” I called out, “I have something for you.” As I admired my find, I heard my wife enter the room and pause. “What is it?” she asked after a moment. I explained that it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were afraid of damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. Although we had never been robbed, I felt anxious and restless. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it underneath.

The law requires that such discoveries be reported to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before handing it over. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I brought it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone with his back to me. When I placed the torc on his desk, he turned around, stopped mid-sentence, and looked surprised. The torc was verified and later sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the landowner and me. However, the torc means much more to me than just a lucky find. I feel like I have preserved a piece of history for the nation. People often say, “Now that you’ve made such a fantastic discovery, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins just as interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing—there’s always the chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my greatest joys when I travel, but I rarely mention it because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends talk about their carefully planned trips filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and stay quiet. What would they think if they knew my travel plans often include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in cozy Italian beds? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. 

When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours—over 12—I spent sleeping each day. There were many loud birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could enjoy a deeper, more dream-filled sleep than I ever expected. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. 

However, I believe that the quality of sleep while traveling is different for a reason. I think sleep is part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we expose ourselves to new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. This flood of new experiences fills us up, and when we sleep, we process all of it. It makes sense that sleep feels more intense when we are away from home.

Sleep also changes from place to place. People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to local cultures than just time differences. For instance, in Trinidad, people wake up at dawn to avoid the heat, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to adapt to their different sleep patterns. When I finally adjust, I feel like I have truly arrived.

I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a large lunch with new Dominican friends in an apartment overlooking the beautiful Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy, and one by one, my friends left the table to lie down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows around. I took some for myself and joined them. I had heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day, I truly experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life.

Travel sleep has another wonderful quality: I remember it. Being far from my usual routine, I enjoy the new scents, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep. If the idea of ‘slow travel’—taking the time to enjoy each experience instead of rushing—is what makes a modern traveler aware, then what could be slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is, in fact, an important part of the journey.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? Be honest," she asked. Mia picked up a medium-sized hat, soft with a nice layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one looks best on you," she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face that resembled a bulldog. "But it’s so boring," she replied. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This beautiful little hat will make me stand out." She sighed and adjusted the red and black miniature top hat on her head. "Yes, this is the one I want," she decided. 

Mia realized she couldn’t change the woman’s mind. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. As she thought about her own daughter, Jen, she remembered it was Jen’s thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since everyone was together, and she looked forward to seeing Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about the friend Jen was bringing, someone they didn’t know. Her husband, Jeff, had quickly pointed this out when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. 

“Tattie?” Jeff had said when Mia shared the news. “What kind of name is that?” 

“It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia replied. “I think it’s nice.” 

“More like something pretentious,” Jeff shot back. He didn’t like anything showy and often criticized Mia for being too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop directly that she was choosing the wrong hat and might have even said a dustbin lid would look better on her. “The problem with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite for your own good.” 

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door; her commute took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to turn the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff had been doubtful. “Do you really think there’s a demand for hats?” he asked. 

Mia knew from her friends that finding the perfect hat for special occasions was difficult, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became successful. Women traveled from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she provided a relaxed atmosphere for them to try on as many hats as they needed. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry as well.

It’s a long journey from London to Atlanta, and at his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident but also surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly starting a new career. Although he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still figuring out what his new role involves. The idea that a 21-year-old beginner from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports seems unbelievable. However, Lawrence is known for proving doubters wrong.

After receiving an offer to study law at Oxford University, he decided to focus on training for the discus instead, having previously played rugby. Within 20 months of starting, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence initially went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for the discus, preparing for the world championships. When asked about his unexpected opportunity in American football, he confirms that it was on his mind, but he only decided to pursue it after arriving in the USA. He had thought about it while in school in London, but it seemed unrealistic then.

Soon after arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had no experience in the sport, he believed he could be good enough to attend the trials. “Pretty much,” he says simply. When asked if he was nervous about competing against experienced players, he replies, “No, not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” Although he is not very talkative, he is confident in his abilities. His performance in various tests impressed the coaches, and he was selected as the standout player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he admits, showing a rare moment of pride.

However, he remains cautious. With no basic experience, how can he make it onto an NFL team? “From what the coaches have told me, I have all the qualities needed. It’s just about how hard I work,” he explains. Will he be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will definitely be chosen, but I’m not too worried.” This calmness may come from his disappointing experience in the Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that moment and takes pride in having qualified for the final with a strong last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he reflects. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. It’s something I can return to.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some speculated that he had let the experience affect him. Lawrence chooses not to comment on that. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, making the financial benefits clear. So, Lawrence has shifted from rugby to athletics and now to American football. Given his many talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would say that,” he replies. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a school kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can always return to the discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to find it was already daylight. Looking out the window at the empty landscape below, the dark shades of brown and green comforted me. Even though it was mid-September, Siberia had not yet changed for autumn. I saw no signs of human life, just a strange mix of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled sleepily. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, saying my name with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow, traveling to the remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was going to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. 

“But, Robert,” he argued, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I told him I believed there was a road, even if not many people used it anymore. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to convince him with hand gestures that I had plenty of warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget for my trip. Most of my clothes and gear were bought at low prices. In truth, I wasn’t sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman’s over-trousers that I had bought for £10.

It all began in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was filled with students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer droned on, and I was deep in thought about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” In front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read, “OK.” 

It was six years later that I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher. Although I still struggled to control my classes fully, the job met many important needs for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and fulfilling, plus there were long holidays to seek adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to visit Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since our first ride together, Al had taken on bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was certainly his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure, facing each new challenge, even when it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong those who said he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through tall pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to participate. An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed that I was healthy, and the second stated that I would empty my pockets, as small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay oriented throughout the experience. I was told, “The horizon is your best friend,” and the pilot would guide me on where to look. I also promised to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I received a safety briefing where I was instructed not to touch anything. As we taxied down the runway, my legs were up, my feet avoided the important steering pedals, and my hands stayed away from the many switches nearby. Despite the instructions, I found it hard to relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying: to survive without fainting, you must stay calm and focused, tensing and relaxing at the right moments. Panicking is not a good idea.

As we began to accelerate down the runway, I felt nervous. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and just two seconds later, we made a sharp right turn. It was a sudden and intense move, and I felt the air rush out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a brief moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out, turned sharply left, and dove down, leaving my stomach behind at 2,000 meters.

Seconds later, we were just 10 meters above the ground, aiming for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, but my excitement was interrupted by another sharp turn. I was allowed to fly the plane for two minutes, but my hand shook so much that the plane shook too, as it is very responsive. Dario spoke to me, but I couldn’t hear him clearly. Instead of answering, he performed a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yes,” I replied. “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over, completing a full circle in the air.

I know many people would find this thrilling, like those who enjoy roller coasters. However, I thought it was overwhelming. At the top of the loop, while upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw fields below. The flight lasted 10 minutes and felt easy compared to what the pilots experience during races. To show this, Dario took out sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about doing loops over and over again.

Doug Allan is a filmmaker who captures wild animals in cold environments. If you have ever been impressed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He prefers a temperature of -18°C. Allan studied marine biology and worked as a commercial diver, which was his first love. Through diving, he learned how to survive in cold conditions. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where he was working, to make a wildlife documentary. He ended up guiding the crew to various locations and realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for him because it involved travel, adventure, and underwater experiences.

Allan has become a leading cameraman and has contributed to many important wildlife TV series. He started his career at a time when few people had explored Antarctica. While there were experts for other animals, he became known as the "cold man." He felt that many incredible scenes were waiting to be filmed. When he began his career 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very basic. He notes that filming is much easier now. In the past, if you recorded something, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot of footage and review it immediately. In the past, you had to carefully plan your shots because film was expensive, but now it is easy to have too much material.

Allan believes his experience in cold environments is valuable. He feels comfortable on sea ice, which now seems as easy as crossing a street to him. Although he sometimes gets cold toes, he finds the polar regions healthy because there are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes. He acknowledges that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and awkward moments. For example, while filming kittiwakes in the Orkneys, he struggled to identify the birds.

Recently, Allan received permission to film in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would be a challenging task, as it is home to polar bears and is only accessible to the bravest or most reckless individuals. In April, temperatures can drop to -32°C, and the strong winds make carrying cameras through deep snow very difficult. After walking for five or more hours each day and observing polar bear dens for 23 days, he had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on the 24th day, he felt as if he was in the world of bears, moving and sensing like them. 

He describes a moment when he spotted a bear. After waiting and watching, he finally saw a bear's nose appear, which quickly became its full head. The bear seemed unbothered by his presence. Just as he thought the moment couldn't get any better, the bear slid down the slope, seemingly enjoying itself. Soon after, two cubs emerged from the den, clearly seeing the world for the first time. Allan felt like he had front-row seats to a spectacular show.

Now, Allan hopes to create his own documentary about climate change in the Arctic, focusing on the people who live there and witness its effects firsthand. He believes he could make an extraordinary film.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold waters and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole as well. Now, he is back in the Arctic, preparing for an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined individuals, which is essential for their work. This time, however, the stakes are much higher. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer trek to the North Pole, where they will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and Pen understands that the results will be crucial for scientists. This research will provide a clearer understanding of how global warming is affecting the polar ice.

Pen was prepared for this kind of work from a young age. He was raised by his father's old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into harsh weather with minimal clothing. His father also inspired his love for adventure in cold places, and Pen developed remarkable physical endurance. He is married to Mary, a horsewoman who shares his passion for the outdoors. Mary helps run his polar guide business and often worries about him more when he is at home, saying, "He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic." For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where horseback riders compete against runners, and she finished an hour ahead of him. 

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He admits that it is much harder to be away from them this time. When he last went on an expedition, his children were one and five years old. He made a mistake in how he said goodbye, telling his son to take care of his mother and sister. His son took this seriously and constantly checked on them, which became too much for him. Although Pen meant well, he feels it was unfair. For this trip, he plans to have very little contact with his family while in the Arctic, as he believes that calling them would only remind them of how far away he is.

In the days leading up to his departure, Pen is meticulously preparing his equipment. He knows that once he is on the ice, it will be very difficult to fix anything or do anything complicated. He will be joined by Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support crew of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen finds being part of a team stressful, and he is also concerned about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained as much as he would like. He explains that organizational tasks often take priority, leaving him anxious about the challenges ahead.

Pen believes that his mission connects exploration with the quest for knowledge that motivated earlier generations to explore the unknown. He admits that reaching the North Pole was mainly a personal goal and had limited value for anyone outside the polar exploration community. This time, however, scientists will benefit from the data collected, and they aim to engage as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. Pen emphasizes that this is important work, and they are uniquely qualified to do it. "Our skills, which may seem strange and unnecessary in everyday life, have become extremely relevant. Suddenly, we are socially useful again," he says.

Text: 'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Although I enjoyed these different activities, I felt there was nothing competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay fit so I could compete for an Olympic spot if that dream came back to me. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about Ben Fogle’s invitation: ‘Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?’ I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very interested. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? Probably not. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben. He was going to participate in the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the other costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We believed we had a better chance than most, but it would still require effort to secure funding. Additionally, I had to consider the loss of income from being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It’s nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about my past without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just be discussing past achievements; I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was tough, with my life focused on getting in the best shape possible, but looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was organized, and I had doctors and dieticians to help. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter. I feared it would seem like I just wanted to be on TV, or else I would have chosen a better partner to win the race. However, my concerns faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. However, he didn’t know how to row. I was surprised by how little natural ability he had with a boat, and he was shocked by my lack of understanding. I could have been more patient, but I felt it was important to be honest with Ben about the significant improvements he needed to make. I should have realized that this would be his level when I agreed to race with him.'

Just over a year ago, I left my job in London to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, perhaps because I was tired of the busy life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a position as a husky dog handler for the winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the snow and ice, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now have over 100. Recently, they acquired a second location called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join their team for three months, but warned me that the hours would be long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical. I began packing right away.

On November 6, while flying to Finland, I stared at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies, trying to memorize their names. I felt distracted and anxious, so I looked out the window instead. I thought about how spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I felt like winter was moving south, freezing the rivers.

On November 7, I took a bus north, which was just as I had hoped. We drove through endless dark forests filled with snow-covered trees, stopping occasionally for reindeer. I arrived at the farm after dark and was quickly given a pair of boots and sent outside into the cold. Anna asked if I wanted to be thrown in at the deep end, and I followed the sound of barking to the dogsheds. There, I saw three people running around, harnessing the excited huskies to sleds. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy. I stood to the side and petted one of the calmer dogs. Someone urged me to get in, and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, guided only by a headlamp.

By November 15, I was starting to learn how to be a husky guide, but first, I faced a tough questioning about my skills. Anna asked if I was useful, and I was unsure. I realized I wasn’t very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. Finally, someone asked if I had a driving license, and I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I quickly learned the basics of dog-sledding: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. However, many other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, saying, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw—in the snow!"

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify her for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about the benefits of emu oil, a natural treatment recommended by Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman to heal injuries Radcliffe suffered when she accidentally collided with a bike during training. Radcliffe said that the significance of her achievement didn’t fully hit her at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it didn’t feel overwhelming. She and her team had decided not to set any limits, following the motto: no limits.

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could maintain her fast pace, fearing it might cause her to drop out. Hartmann was upset by this concern, although he acknowledged that anyone unfamiliar with her fitness might see it as a risk to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe began to think about her finish time. She realized she could complete the race in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she finished the last stretch in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at a fast pace, she managed to sprint the final distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never expected anyone to come close to that time for a long time, and she thought, "I will come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that did not happen.

After the race, many were curious about how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, managed to outperform the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked closely with Radcliffe for weeks, providing daily training sessions to support her as she ran 250-300 kilometers each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one else could handle that level of pain. She would push me to my limits; I had to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for pleasantries; she was ready for a two-hour training session. "Paula would push you to give everything you had. That’s what made her so successful." Hartmann dedicated so much time to Radcliffe that other athletes he worked with became resentful.

When asked if Radcliffe could explain why no one has come close to her record, she replied, "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, might achieve it. Maybe it’s because people are competing against each other instead of focusing on their own performance." She explained, "That mindset of never easing up, even when you’re winning, probably helped me because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always about pushing myself as hard as I could."

Radcliffe did not realize at the time that this marathon was the peak of her career, and she would never run that fast again. However, she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At that time, there was a lot of discussion about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain. I believed we had created a series that truly contributed to this movement, but I still worried: would people enjoy a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both excited and anxious. Fortunately, I needn’t have worried. The show became very successful, leading to many interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I later wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving passports, suitcases, and travel plans. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who finds joy in making golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. 

Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to feature in the series was challenging, and I knew I would disappoint some people by not including their favorites. I could imagine them asking, “Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that would satisfy everyone. This experience reinforced my belief that each person has their own view of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and environment. Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the ultimate versions. I believed that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. 

The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. It’s about trying ideas and refining them until something unique emerges. The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen in restaurants, and I was excited to delve into the memories and nostalgia connected to food, as I began my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, such as visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which forced us to stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking like he knew what he was doing. Finally, he said, “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, saying, “We can’t stay here forever.” The field was big and empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea, saying, “No, we can’t stay here forever.” We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass and said, “Tell us a story.” Bea lay down next to her and encouraged me to tell a story. I shared how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking about breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. Bea said, “That’s silly, no one understands bird language.” My eyes felt teary. I said, “I do,” but I didn’t sound very sure. Bea called me a liar, and I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? I thought about asking Mum, but she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out, but the boys waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” Mum reassured him, saying, “We’ll just have some tea,” and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, “It’s like syrup in there.” We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. When it started to get dark, he said, “I guess it’s a miracle it got us this far.” Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on solid ground. John said, “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech.” 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home since our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like she was. One was a man from Tokyo, and the other was a woman from a European city whose name Lucy didn’t quite hear, maybe Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I’m doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said, trying to sound impressive. However, she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she was no longer officially enrolled. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She had been selected from thousands of applicants. There had been a celebration, and her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her. Her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the application and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to give her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about trying to back out.

The man from Tokyo leaned in, seeming surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah,” Lucy replied. “How old are you?” he asked. “Fifteen,” she said. He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag; it was hard to know when she was just sharing her experiences or showing off. “It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying…” Liesel/Louisa interrupted, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The man from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool even if they loved music.

“Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. He started to respond when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said.

Later, in the elevator to their suite, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” She liked that part—being recognized. Even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she received. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, wouldn’t care that she could play a difficult Rachmaninov piece perfectly. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

Text: "‘Spending too much time online isn’t good for you. You should spend more time in the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I looked into what experts say about this topic, and I found it quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a large group of real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an expert in online safety, states that ‘social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, describes it as ‘the modern version of hanging out at the youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. It’s like a virtual youth club.’ He explains that it helps teenagers form their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues while connecting with their peers. 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says, ‘Adolescence is a time for discovering who you are. Social networking can help with this self-discovery: you can share your favorite music or sports, find out what you enjoy, and see that others have different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can be helpful for shy people: ‘Talking online can be easier than in person, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less intimidating way.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can be beneficial for quiet individuals with specific interests because they connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But finding a social networking group of similar people can make you feel connected and popular in a different way,’ he explains. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared an interesting point: ‘Young people who discover new interests online, join networks of like-minded individuals, and create their own content are truly making the most of social networks.’ She believes social networking is becoming a creative outlet: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing how we express creativity. Passionate photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interests. ‘This enhances employability and will be valuable in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to promote and build brand awareness – understanding how it works is essential. For instance, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on various social networks, they could all be potential customers. Linking these networks creates your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, Matthews agrees. ‘One great feature of many sites is the chance to collaborate with others to create and share content. Collaboration is a vital skill in the 21st century and is important for being employable in a digital world.’"

When people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not interested in a quiet getaway when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he called the ultimate family bonding experience, which my twin brother and I found terrifying. “Not enough people do this anymore,” my parents said repeatedly, while we exchanged worried looks.

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left for us, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our spacious home for smaller places over the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we had gotten ourselves into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. The desert changed to mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best for actual Jeep drivers.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed at the large “CLOSED” signs in front of the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. We experienced “bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, and had a memorable encounter with a bear and a nervous park ranger.

As we continued driving, life back home felt distant, and even our hotel, which was an old building with no internet or cell service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. Instead, I enjoyed some of the most beautiful views I had ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we began our journey back south. My parents were right; you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something amazing. 

Returning home was a mix of emotions, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our adventure to look through, and I knew that the best memories would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so it was better for her to remain there. She was happy to have the best room at her college, which included a kitchen and study area, along with free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. 

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had vague memories of her grandmother from past holidays and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy was eager to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents had issues with her grandmother, but there had been a disagreement in the past, leading to summers spent away from Daisy. Rose remembered her last goodbye at age ten, and those memories were happy. Dahlia suggested that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical frail old lady; she seemed to attend more social events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She understood healthy eating, fitness, and the importance of sleep. However, she wanted her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without always asking for permission. She believed she could be trusted with these small things. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or curfews, and she didn’t want to be controlled by her grandmother. Daisy understood this.

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed that their relationship would be based on trust. Daisy would trust Rose to make mature decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it again.

Rose was not a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her a lot. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years of school. For Rose, this was a new chapter in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to think she might write a novel. She felt that writing a book was a big challenge and, unlike other teenagers who aimed for things like the Olympics, she decided to try writing when she turned 13. Now, the novel she started at that age is about to be published. When she recently told her former teacher about it, the teacher was surprised, as she had expected Charlotte to write a book when she was much older, around 30 or 40. Charlotte found it strange that she should wait to pursue something she felt she could be good at.

On a winter afternoon, I met Charlotte in her publisher's office. I was surprised to see a 15-year-old girl sitting there, even though I knew I was interviewing a teenager about her book. The book is a significant achievement; it is well-written and exciting. The only thing that reveals its young author is the age of the main character. A public relations representative was present, but Charlotte did not need any support. She is confident, intelligent, and grounded, showing a maturity beyond her years.

Charlotte recognizes the limits of her youth. When I asked her about the complex moral questions in her book, she said she was more interested in asking big questions than providing answers. She laughed, saying she doesn’t think her age limits her understanding of the world, but she also doesn’t consider herself particularly wise. She wanted to explore the theme of taking responsibility.

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in fiction. She believes there are three common types of teenage characters: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the socially awkward teen. She found it frustrating to see these stereotypes repeated. She wondered, “What if you’re just fine?” Many stories suggest that teenagers are inadequate or lost, which can harm their self-confidence.

Although Charlotte enjoys reading works by famous fantasy authors, she admits that their depth sometimes discouraged her from writing. She questioned whether she needed to explore such complex themes to write well. However, she found helpful advice in a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which taught her that if readers can predict what will happen next, the suspense is likely gone.

Some might think that Charlotte's parents, both journalists, played a crucial role in getting her novel published. Her father's connections in publishing helped her get her book read. She is grateful for this opportunity, as it is challenging for any new writer to have their first novel read, regardless of age. She believes that every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but ultimately, success depends on their talent. Charlotte concludes that she does not take her achievements for granted.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show off, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He approached the ramp quickly and flew into the air, arms flailing. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly reminded us, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ Maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t like those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes at skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I felt I would be ridiculed if I tried to join them with their baggy pants and special slang. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a large indoor facility with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow, where students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits – not a realistic way to prepare for the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their skills for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan cheerfully promised. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope becomes the landing zone. Landing in the zone allows you to continue moving forward, reducing impact. Landing on the flat stops you suddenly, which is painful. So, speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain’s fears and race towards the jump. My legs seemed to go backward as I neared the launch point, and I landed hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. 

Day two began on the trampolines. I thought I would dislike being indoors while looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some drills mimicked ski-jumping moves, while others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – understanding what your body is doing while spinning in the air. Gareth provided commentary. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – I was only aware of the moment before take-off and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed correctly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I noticed both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you grip the harness tightly. Suddenly, the ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. There’s a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel weightless. You rush forward, turn sharply to the left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

What surprises me is how big the amusement park industry is, with thrilling rides designed to attract crowds. Behind the scenes, there are many creative and skilled engineers, designers, and marketing experts working hard. The idea of being a "rollercoaster designer" might sound like a childhood dream, but it is actually a tough job. Designers must find the right mix of excitement and safety while also introducing new features to keep visitors interested. 

While many people think rollercoasters are becoming more extreme, most of the techniques used today were developed by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. During his time, there were fewer safety regulations, and some rides were quite uncomfortable for passengers. Now, designers must work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers.

I spoke with three experts in rollercoaster design. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," explained that the skill lies in putting all the elements together. Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, added that it’s about quickly alternating between thrilling and calming sensations so that riders feel excited but safe. 

To create an amazing ride, teams must develop a strong story, whether it’s a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with exciting features like the tallest drops or the most twists. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director in theme park development, agreed that understanding what riders want and testing the rides before they open is important.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to use new technologies like virtual reality. Walker responded that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, the physical thrill of the ride will always be the main attraction. New technologies come and go, but the core experience of riding a rollercoaster will remain essential for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating performances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both in her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the instructions of strict choreographers, which can be stressful. Choreographers sometimes forget how it feels to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, she takes on a teaching role and enjoys working with young dancers. “Beginners are often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, it’s easier to work with students than professionals because they are willing to take risks. They are eager to succeed but don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of clarity helps them accept even tough criticism. However, they might still question my advice, and I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, guided by the music. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still strive to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. Ideally, I would like to experiment more and have the option to switch music, which would help improve the atmosphere during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on large productions where the music is already decided and cannot be changed.”

Miranda believes in making connections with new people rather than sticking to one institution. “It’s important to meet new people, but I must remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my approach each time I work somewhere new, which helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

We discuss a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “Previous glamorous documentaries have been misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that struggle. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s genuine. The public often underestimates the hard work and dedication required in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. “It’s when everything the company has worked on – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. While perfection is hard to achieve, aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help cover up some artistic mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are excellent, but distracting costumes or props can be disappointing.”

Given her diverse work, I wonder how she defines herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet expert? “People like to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to specialize in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing. For now, I want to broaden my experiences.”

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that TV shows us amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main focus of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it, attaching them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I placed my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even spending one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at cafés and enjoy a cappuccino on the sofa instead of having my sandwiches blown away while sitting on a rock. I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be a good idea.
