The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and let me on the ferry.

Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper swim of 1.5 km, which made me nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The following days had a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful scenery. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt less need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come back again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not an easy job, but it has many rewards. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me!

As a child, I attended a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me when I decided to leave my banking job and look for a new career.

At the interview for the flight attendant position, there were many young people, and many of us were hired. Like me, they were often well-qualified and looking to change careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I wanted to stand out, so instead of just saying I loved to travel, I talked about my skills and past work experience. This approach helped me get the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because it has many benefits, although the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: "no one is finished until everyone is finished." It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other often, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take my job home with me. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I remind myself that the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy watching the children achieve things they never thought they could. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some children feel nervous at first, but with encouragement, they decide to try, and eventually, they all reach the top. This accomplishment makes them feel wonderful.

At the start of the week, some children miss their homes. Interestingly, it is not the younger ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We limit their use of mobile phones. We first tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, often after dinner, we explain that it is too late to call and suggest they do it the next day. Most children adjust within a couple of days, and by the end of their stay, they come to us to express their gratitude for the enjoyable time they had.

It is not only the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who frequently call to check on their child, which is often unnecessary. Their child is usually busy playing games or engaging in other activities, so we have to ask the parents to call back later.

We often see a certain type of child at camp, typically dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into more appropriate attire, but soon they understand the reason behind our request.

'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be skilled musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was difficult. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. This meant that they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

Even though the theatre in London is larger than the one in the USA, it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ I asked him what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to join him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! Although the young actors were already musicians, some playing multiple instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the challenging part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
